Say no to words that hurt

Many parents have rules against swearing, but swear words aren't the only words that hurt. Take turns reading aloud with your child

Reading aloud with your child is a great way to help her become a better reader. Choose a short passage from a book at your child's reading level. Read it aloud to her. (Be sure to use lots of expression in your voice.) Then have her read the passage back to you. If she struggles with a word, remind her what it is, then let her continue reading. Don't worry if it takes a few times before your child can read the text easily.

Are after-school activities helping or hurting your child?

After-school activities can enrich your child's life. But sometimes, even a good thing can be too much. From time to time, review your child's schedule. Does she enjoy all her activities? Does she have time to get her schoolwork finished? Does she have time to read, play and relax? Do her activities cause her stress? If you suspect your child is over-scheduled, talk with her about dropping an activity.

You ARE qualified to help your child learn math

You can help your child learn math even if you don't remember any of the math you took in school. Here are some tips: Ask your child questions about his math homework, such as "How did you arrive at that answer?" or "Look at the page of problems. Do you see a pattern?" Involve your child in the everyday math you do at home, such as measuring. And build daily math practice into your child's routine.

Successful learners do more than just listen

To learn well, your child needs to do more than just listen in class. She needs to arrive at school well-rested and prepared, with completed homework and supplies. In class, she should ask questions, offer opinions and participate in discussions. At home, help her create a system she can use to organize her schoolwork. Encourage your child to be persistent, and show confidence that her efforts will pay off!
